Assaf Arkin wrote:
> On Sat, Dec 20, 2008 at 1:45 PM, Bill de hOra <bill@... 
> <mailto:bill@...>> wrote:
> 
>     Etan Wexler wrote:
> 
>      >> It must be noted that the incubator (just like the board) does not
>      >> perform filtering on the basis of technical issues. This is because
>      >> the foundation respects and suggests variety of technical
>     approaches.
>      >> It doesn't fear innovation or even internal confrontation between
>      >> projects which overlap in functionality.
>      >
>      > Do I need to comment further?
> 
>     The point is this - why is the API called RESTful? That's not a
>     technical issue.
> 
> 
> If I had a dollar for every project/person who thinks REST is short for 
> RPC over HTTP (now with 100% more Verbs!) ...

What do you think will happen if the ASF is asked to remoniker that page 
to say an "RPC API" ?


> The point of incubation is to create a self-governing community around 
> the project, and that includes a place to discuss these things, 
> specifically the ESME dev mailing list.  If the original developers 
> didn't know REST well enough, here's the chance of get involved and 
> sprinkle some REST goodness there.

I get more done posting criticism here or on a weblog. I don't want to 
go around fixing broken APIs, but I would like them to be named for what 
they are.  It's not as though the ASF community doesn't have members who 
  can do this.


> It's also possible this is the odor of corporate branding applied to the 
> project in its pre-Apache days.  Incubation is the chance to shed 
> the corporate/proprietary mentality and grow into an open 
> source/community.  If you can't do that, you don't graduate, so when 
> voting to accept a project for incubation, it's about the possibility of 
> it becoming an Apache project, less so about the raw materials.

All right and true, but beside the point.

Bill
